articles.title: Victoria to force agents to publish property reserve prices in crackdown on underquoting
articles.trailText: Under the nation-first laws, real estate agents in Victoria will be required to disclose owner’s reserve price within seven days of sale or face penalties
articles.summary: Victoria will require agents to disclose owner reserve prices at least seven days before auction or fixed-date sale under nation-first reforms aimed at curbing illegal underquoting, which analysis shows occurs in up to 20% of Sydney sales and 18% in Perth. Failure to publish means an agent cannot proceed to sell and risks fines up to A$11,000 per breach or A$38,000 under the Estate Agents Act. Agents must update all marketing materials and retain records of comparable-property selection for Consumer Affairs Victoria. Similar NSW rules impose A$22,000 fines and commission forfeiture.

articles.title: Ocado shares fall 17% after US partner announces warehouse closures
articles.trailText: Online grocer had a deal with Kroger to build 20 customer fulfilment centres but three of the sites are to close
articles.summary: Ocado shares dropped 17% after US partner Kroger said it would close three of 20 automated customer fulfilment centres in Maryland, Wisconsin and Florida. Kroger is shifting to a “hybrid fulfilment network” combining store-based automation with services like DoorDash, Instacart and Uber Eats, aiming to optimise costs. Ocado expects about $250m in early-termination fees but to lose $50m in FY26 revenue. Analysts warn these closures deal a “knockout punch” to Ocado’s US expansion plans and question the viability of capital-intensive centralised warehouses in dispersed markets.

articles.title: ‘No contract, no coffee’: what to know about the Starbucks workers’ strike in over 40 US cities
articles.trailText: Starbucks union threatens to expand campaign as politicians like Zohran Mamdani back striking workers
articles.summary: Since Nov 13, over 1,000 Starbucks baristas across 40+ US cities have launched an open-ended “No contract, no coffee” strike, targeting 65 outlets and urging customers to boycott the chain’s flagship holiday “red cup day.” The walkout follows stalled talks over Starbucks’ first US union contract—covering pay, benefits and labor practices—and dozens of unfair labor practice charges filed by Starbucks Workers United, which represents 11,000 staff at 550 stores. Backers include NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani and Seattle mayor-elect Katie Wilson. Starbucks says over 99% of locations remain open, blaming the union for the impasse and touting its $30/hr+ average compensation.

articles.title: WH Smith CEO quits after accounting error that wiped almost £600m off value
articles.trailText: Company slashes profit outlook as it takes hit from blunder in North American division
articles.summary: WH Smith CEO Carl Cowling resigned after an independent Deloitte review revealed accounting failures in the North American division that overstated US profits by up to £50m, triggering a 42% share plunge that erased £600m in market value. The group slashed its US 2024–25 profit forecast to £5–15m from £55m, and cut full-year group earnings to £100–110m, down 55%. Andrew Harrison, UK chief executive, will serve as interim CEO. Chair Annette Court apologised, pledging stronger controls, governance and oversight. The retailer, focusing on travel outlets, aims to rebuild trust and profitability in North America under new leadership.

articles.title: Harvard to investigate Larry Summers’s Epstein ties as he exits OpenAI board
articles.trailText: Newly released Epstein documents drag the ex-treasury secretary into deeper scrutiny as Harvard widens its review
articles.summary: Harvard has launched a new inquiry into ex-president Larry Summers’s links with Jeffrey Epstein, days after emails revealed Summers sought advice from the convicted sex offender and described him as his “wingman.” Summers, who also stepped down from the OpenAI board and relinquished roles at Bloomberg, the New York Times and CAP, pledged to focus on teaching while stepping back from public life. The probe extends to affiliates named in the 23,000 released documents—including his wife—and follows prior Harvard and MIT reviews of Epstein’s donations and influence.

articles.title: The days of 4% pay rises are behind us – wages are now barely growing faster than inflation | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: The recovery of real wages is expected to be so slow that it will take us until 2044 to get back to having as much purchasing power as in 2021
articles.summary: In Q3 private-sector wages rose just 0.7% (down from 0.8% Q2 and 0.9% Q1) while annual growth has fallen below 4%. Public-sector pay edged up to 3.8%, largely driven by state government awards, yet since March 2021 private wages (15.2%) have outpaced public (14.2%). Meanwhile inflation (+21.8%) and living costs (+26.6%) outstrip wage gains, leaving real wages 4.6% below March 2021. A $90k full-time salary now has the purchasing power of $85,862, a $4,138 loss. At current RBA projections, real purchasing power won’t return until 2044.

articles.title: UK inflation eases for first time in five months to 3.6% before crunch budget
articles.trailText: Drop in October’s annual rate raises hopes of interest rate cut after Rachel Reeves’s tax and spending statement
articles.summary: In October UK inflation fell to 3.6% from 3.8%, the first drop in five months, as slower energy and hotel price rises offset 4.9% food inflation. The ONS figure matched City forecasts, below the Bank of England’s 3.7% projection but above its 2% target. Ahead of Rachel Reeves’s 26 November budget—likely to include energy VAT cuts and a private dental cost probe—the decline boosts hopes of a December rate cut after core inflation eased to 3.4% and markets priced an 85% chance. Economists caution on a possible pre-budget rebound.

articles.title: Netherlands suspends state seizure of Chinese chipmaker Nexperia
articles.trailText: Dutch government’s move pauses dispute that threatened car production around the world
articles.summary: The Dutch government has suspended its September 30 order to seize supervisory control of Chinese-owned chipmaker Nexperia under the Goods Availability Act as a goodwill gesture to Beijing after six weeks of trade tensions that halted auto production. Minister Vincent Karremans praised recent talks with Chinese authorities and noted that China lifted its export ban, allowing chips to flow again to Volkswagen and Honda plants. The Netherlands retains the right to reimpose control if Nexperia threatens EU production or intellectual property. Nexperia and European carmakers urge a binding supply agreement and full legal resolution.

articles.title: Fall in UK inflation looks like turning point that heralds interest rate cut
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves hints there will be budget measures to push down prices and Bank of England is likely to act
articles.summary: CPI eased to 3.6% in October from 3.8%, marking a potential turning point. Chancellor Rachel Reeves signals next week’s budget may include measures — notably a 5% VAT cut on energy and competition reforms in dentistry and vet sectors — to hasten inflation’s descent ahead of the next election. The BoE’s MPC remains split: Governor Bailey held rates at 4%, hawks like Pill cite wage risks, while doves such as Dhingra favour cuts. Financial markets price an 82% chance of a rate cut in December, pending fresh inflation, unemployment, and wage data. BoE forecasts inflation will hit its 2% target by 2027.

articles.title: Ocado’s share price is back where it started. Are its robots just too fancy?
articles.trailText: Delivery company struggling to convince US chain Kroger, its most important customer, of the virtues of automation
articles.summary: Ocado’s shares have fallen from a 2020 peak of £29 back to its 2009 IPO level of 180p, after US partner Kroger announced it will close three of eight automated warehouses and expand cheaper delivery options with DoorDash, Instacart and Uber Eats. Kroger’s review suggests Ocado’s high-spec robotics only pay off in high-density locations, undermining the original plan for 20 US sites. Ocado gets $250m compensation but must now prove how its capital-intensive model can scale profitably.

articles.title: Visma approaches City grandee to act as chair if €20bn London listing goes ahead
articles.trailText: Norwegian software group looks to ex-Worldpay boss Sir Ron Kalifa as it weighs up blockbuster flotation in London or Stockholm
articles.summary: Visma has tapped ex-Worldpay boss Sir Ron Kalifa to chair its potential €20bn London IPO next spring, contingent on choosing London over a rival Stockholm listing. Backed by Hg Capital for two decades, the Oslo-based software group is gauging demand with fund managers and is advised by Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and UBS. While Stockholm benefits from recent float success (Verisure €13.7bn IPO), London hopes Kalifa’s fintech credentials and the absence of large recent listings will tip the decision. Visma serves 2.2m customers with AI-driven accounting, payroll and HR software.

articles.title: Klarna says AI drive has helped halve staff numbers and boost pay
articles.trailText: Buy now, pay later firm says pay has risen by 60% with staff numbers mostly cut by attrition and tech investment
articles.summary: Over the past three years, Klarna slashed headcount from 5,527 to 2,907 via attrition and AI automation—an internal AI programme cut outsourced customer service, raising automated capacity from 700 to 853 FTEs—boosting revenues 108% while keeping costs flat. Average compensation jumped 60% to $203k as CEO Sebastian Siemiatkowski channelled savings into pay, lifting revenue per employee to $1.1m. Q3 revenue rose 26% to $903m but net loss widened to $95m after US accounting changes tied to its NYSE listing. Further job cuts likely as AI rollout continues, though he warned against costly datacentre builds.

articles.title: ExxonMobil to shut chemicals plant in Fife with loss of up to 450 jobs
articles.trailText: US oil firm blames UK government policy and supply costs for closure of site near Cowdenbeath
articles.summary: ExxonMobil will close its 40-year-old Fife Ethylene Plant near Cowdenbeath by February, citing uncompetitive UK economic and policy conditions, high supply costs and inefficiency. Around 200 staff and 250 contractors face redundancy after failed talks with Westminster and no buyer emerged. The industry minister said government support was offered but lacked a viable business case, promising job placement support. Scottish ministers and local MPs decried the loss of up to 450 high-value jobs, pledging taskforces and community aid as Exxon proceeds with global restructuring including 2,000 role cuts elsewhere. Government said officials explored every avenue but deemed required £1bn investment too high.

articles.title: Crest Nicholson plans job cuts and warns on profits, blaming budget uncertainty
articles.trailText: Housebuilder’s autumn selling season was wiped out by speculation about new property taxes, says analyst
articles.summary: Crest Nicholson, the Surrey-based housebuilder, will close one divisional office and cut 50 roles after warning adjusted pre-tax profit for the year to 31 October will sit at or below its £28–38 m guidance. It blames subdued summer sales and prolonged budget speculation over stamp duty, income tax rises and a mansion tax. RBC Capital Markets says uncertainty wiped out the critical autumn season. Crest completed 1,691 homes (35% affordable), saw weekly site sales drop to 0.45 units, sold five land parcels, is trimming its landbank, rolling out new house types and launching a multi-year turnaround plan, expecting future policy support to spur demand.

articles.title: Eight firms under investigation in crackdown on additional online fees
articles.trailText: Competition watchdog examines StubHub, Viagogo, AA Driving School and BSM Driving School and others
articles.summary: Britain’s CMA has launched its first probes under new consumer-protection laws into eight firms—ticket platforms StubHub and Viagogo; AA-owned driving schools BSM and AA Driving School; US gym chain Gold’s Gym; and retailers Wayfair, Appliances Direct and Marks Electrical—over hidden fees, drip pricing and banned countdown timers. Following a cross-sector review of 400+ businesses, the regulator can now order compensation and fine up to 10% of global turnover. All firms say they’re cooperating, and CMA chief Sarah Cardell stressed the need for fair, transparent pricing.

articles.title: Lawyers for Fed governor accuse Trump administration of ‘cherry-picking’ facts in fraud case
articles.trailText: Lisa Cook’s lawyer details defense against accusations she misrepresented residences to get better mortgage rate
articles.summary: Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook's lawyers, in a letter to AG Pam Bondi and DAG Edward Martin, label the Trump administration's mortgage fraud claims "baseless" and accuse it of cherry-picking discrepancies in her Ann Arbor home, Atlanta condo and Cambridge property. Abbe Lowell presents loan documents and disclosures showing an isolated, inadvertent notation on the Atlanta condo application and consistent listings of her residences, arguing no intent to defraud. He also criticizes FHFA director William Pulte for selectively targeting Trump critics while ignoring similar discrepancies among administration officials. The Supreme Court reinstated Cook and will hear her removal case in January.

articles.title: UK officials ‘working day and night’ to resolve NHS drug pricing row’
articles.trailText: Patrick Vallance says government trying to rebuild relations with pharma industry as he outlines life sciences ambition
articles.summary: Science minister Patrick Vallance said UK officials are ‘working day and night’ to end a standoff with major pharma over NHS drug pricing after talks collapsed in August, prompting MSD, AstraZeneca and Eli Lilly to pause UK investments. Ministers aim to raise cost-effectiveness thresholds for NHS drug approvals by about 25%. Negotiations involve business adviser Varun Chandra and follow global pricing pressures including US tariff threats under Donald Trump. Vallance highlighted new investments—Moderna (£150m), BioNTech (£1bn) and Convatec (£500m)—as part of ambitions to make the UK Europe’s leading life sciences hub by 2030.

articles.title: GWR train fitted with F1 tech for two-month superfast wifi trial
articles.trailText: Tryout of system, which switches between signals from 5G masts to low Earth-orbit satellites, could lead to wider rollout
articles.summary: GWR has begun a two-month trial on one of its 57 intercity express trains using F1-derived tech from Motion Applied to switch between 5G masts, Wi-Fi and low Earth orbit satellites, delivering speeds above 120 Mbps, enough for Netflix, video calls and streaming. Funded by the DfT and Peninsula Transport (£300k) with £41 m further investment, the trial complements black-spot elimination and station 5G upgrades, aiming for network-wide rollout by 2030 and productivity gains. Similar systems are entering service on Deutsche Bahn, Brightline and Amtrak.

articles.title: TotalEnergies buys €5.1bn stake in Czech tycoon’s power plants business
articles.trailText: Daniel Křetínský to become a major shareholder in French oil firm as part of deal creating 50/50 joint venture
articles.summary: Daniel Křetínský sells a 50% stake in his European power generation arm, Energetický a průmyslový holding (EPH), to TotalEnergies for €5.1bn, receiving about 4.1% of Total’s share capital. The 50/50 joint venture will own UK assets (including Lynemouth and Kilroot stations serving over 3m homes) and generation sites in France, the Netherlands and Italy, deepening Total’s gas-to-power integration, LNG network and European power trading. Křetínský, ranked 22nd on the Sunday Times rich list (£7.79bn), holds stakes in Royal Mail, West Ham United and retailers. Separately, Octopus Group’s Eclipse Power acquires 20 UK distribution projects from Vattenfall.

articles.title: Thames Water bidder says it is offering £1bn extra cash injection
articles.trailText: Castle Water says restructuring plans do not go far enough and extra funds will help resolve pollution crisis
articles.summary: Castle Water, led by CEO John Reynolds, has offered to boost its £4 bn bid for Thames Water with an additional £1 bn of equity, arguing creditor-led restructuring falls short on pollution remediation. Thames, saddled with £17 bn net debt and controlled by hedge funds Elliott and Silver Point, faces plans that could delay full compliance with environmental rules for up to 15 years. Reynolds demands zero-tolerance on serious spills, targeting immediate upgrades at Mogden sewage works, financed via deeper creditor haircuts and fresh equity. Meanwhile, creditors insist talks with Ofwat are on track, planning £20.5 bn investment over five years, and Thames aims to finalise a market-led recapitalisation by Christmas.

articles.title: WPP shares leap amid takeover bid speculation
articles.trailText: Advertising group declines to comment on reports of interest from rival Havas and private equity groups Apollo and KKR
articles.summary: WPP’s shares jumped 11% on heavy takeover chatter, as rival Havas—controlled by Vincent Bolloré—and private equity groups Apollo and KKR have held internal discussions about bids for the £3bn-valued advertising giant. Apollo has ruled out a bid; KKR declined comment. WPP, down over 80% in market value since 2017 amid profit warnings and client losses, is under review by new CEO Cindy Rose. Analysts see its media arm, managing $60bn of ad spend, as more valuable than WPP’s £7.5bn enterprise value. The move follows broader consolidation: Omnicom’s $13.5bn IPG deal and Dentsu’s international sale.

articles.title: Reeves could allow holiday tax on English hotel and Airbnb stays
articles.trailText: Move to give mayors powers to raise funds through levies, but industry says it will ramp up prices and inflation
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s 26 November budget will propose power for English mayors to impose a nightly 5% tourist levy on hotel and Airbnb stays—on top of 20% VAT and VAT on the charge—raising an estimated £518m from 89m trips (255m nights) to invest in transport and services. UKHospitality warns this will drive up consumer costs and inflation. The levy, enacted via amendments to the English devolution and community empowerment bill, mirrors similar schemes in Scotland and Wales. Reeves is also set to end the VAT exemption on milk-based drinks under the sugar tax, lowering the sugar threshold to generate £50m–£100m.

articles.title: FCA’s first deputy CEO calls for stronger grip on vital tech firms
articles.trailText: Sarah Pritchard suggests City regulator will make use of oversight powers amid growing number of outages
articles.summary: Sarah Pritchard, FCA’s first deputy CEO, warns the UK must strengthen regulatory control over foreign tech firms powering banks after repeated outages and cyberattacks—most recently an AWS glitch that disrupted over 2,000 firms including Lloyds and the LSE. Though the Treasury granted the FCA, PRA and BoE powers in early 2025 to designate critical third parties and enforce incident reporting and contingency planning, no firms have yet been named. Pritchard urges joint supervision and warns against complacency as digital banking failures mount.

articles.title: Asking prices fall as UK housing market hit by budget speculation, Rightmove says
articles.trailText: November drop of 1.8% is biggest for this time of year since 2012, with chancellor’s plans looming
articles.summary: Rightmove data show UK seller asking prices fell 1.8% (£6,589) month-on-month in November to £364,833—the steepest seasonal drop since 2012—as 34% of listings cut prices by an average 7%. Experts attribute the slump to pre-budget jitters over potential stamp duty and tax changes, a glut of supply and an early Christmas lull. Properties under £500k have held steadier. Separately, EY’s Item Club projects UK mortgage lending growth to slow from 3.2% in 2025 to 2.8% in 2026 amid stretched affordability and real-income constraints, with a rebound expected in 2027–28.

articles.title: Joe Rigby obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Head of programme planning for Granada Television in Manchester for 20 years
articles.summary: Joe Rigby, died aged 87, Birmingham-born working-class Catholic, left school at 15 and rose through TV ranks to become Granada Television’s head of programme planning (1973–1994). He hired and mentored scriptwriters including Andy Harries, David Liddiment, Dearbhla Walsh and Lee Child (Jim Grant), earned the nickname “Fifth Beatle,” and championed northern ITV programming and scheduling prominence. An international ambassador at Cannes and Monte Carlo, he left Granada over its profit-first shift and retired to Spain, later Dorset, where he sang in a church choir. He is survived by wife Josie, three children, four grandchildren, brother Patrick and sister Catherine.

articles.title: Merchants’ ‘victory’ over credit card fees will just complicate things more for them
articles.trailText: Do small business owners think that Visa and Mastercard won’t just recoup their fees elsewhere?
articles.summary: After years of battling Visa and Mastercard over processing fees, small merchants celebrated a settlement lowering rates on some low-rewards cards. But the win saddles them with complicated tiered pricing, potential rejection of high-fee cards, and extra POS integration costs. Reduced merchant fees will also erode credit-card reward partnerships that drive customer spending and referrals—benefits many small businesses rely on. Meanwhile, card networks will recoup revenue through higher annual and penalty fees, raised interest margins, and surcharges passed on by banks. The so-called victory ultimately adds operational headaches, hidden costs and risks alienating customers rather than cutting expenses.

articles.title: UK watchdogs need to step in on rip-off bills, which are bad for consumers and the economy | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: From mobiles to insurance and subscriptions, firms are able to exploit the fact they know more than customers
articles.summary: Economists Andrew Sissons and John Springford warn that weak competition, complex tariffs and ineffective regulation in services – from energy and telecoms to insurance and subscriptions – fuel persistent inflation and harm consumers. They urge the government to bolster watchdogs: ban ‘RPI-plus’ auto-renewals outside essentials, enforce online cancellation for all digital subscriptions, and introduce plain-vanilla standard products. Better-funded, more interventionist regulators could drive down bills, boost market efficiency and ease cost-of-living pressures ahead of Rachel Reeves’s November budget.

articles.title: ‘I think the city is falling apart’: Leicester braces for a make-or-break budget
articles.trailText: In the local authority where people have the least spare cash there are hopes the chancellor will instil change
articles.summary: Leicester, with the lowest per-capita disposable income in England, is grappling with an entrenched cost-of-living crisis: families share cramped Victorian homes, debt on energy bills has soared past £4.5bn, and public services have been slashed. Anti-poverty charities report clients juggling multiple jobs yet struggling to pay rent and utilities. As residents plead for relief, Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s 26 Nov budget—promising welfare cap relief, free school meals expansion, administered-price caps and minimum wage rises—could be a lifeline. However, constrained council budgets, weak local industry and a stalled rail upgrade mean investment may bypass Leicester, deepening deprivation and social care strains.

articles.title: UK budget watchdog in danger of strangling economic growth, says TUC boss
articles.trailText: Paul Nowak says OBR should be modernised to ditch ‘hardwired’ support for austerity economics
articles.summary: TUC general secretary Paul Nowak warns that the OBR’s entrenched austerity bias risks strangling UK growth ahead of Rachel Reeves’s Nov 26 budget. He urges an urgent post-budget review of the OBR’s role after a late productivity downgrade—trimmed by 0.3 percentage points and hitting public finances by up to £20bn—forcing expected tax rises and spending cuts to meet fiscal rules. Since its 2010 founding, the watchdog has acted as an “austerity cheerleader” and underestimated long-term investment gains. Nowak proposes a single annual forecast to replace twice-yearly updates. The IMF also backs annual rule assessments.

articles.title: Business secretary backs shift to electric arc furnaces at British Steel plant
articles.trailText: Move would secure future of steel production at Scunthorpe but raise questions over future of blast furnaces
articles.summary: Business secretary Peter Kyle has signaled government support for replacing Scunthorpe’s blast furnaces at British Steel with electric arc furnaces (EAFs) to secure low-carbon steel output and meet UK net zero targets. Abandoning primary blast furnaces raises concerns about jobs, Britain’s ability to produce virgin steel from iron ore, and prior pledges to retain primary steelmaking. Kyle, preparing a December steel strategy, confirmed hundreds of millions spent to keep British Steel and Liberty Steel afloat, and is exploring hydrogen-based direct reduced iron facilities compatible with EAFs. It hinges on a deal with Jingye Steel and has drawn cautious support from unions urging a just transition.

articles.title: One of Britain’s biggest housebuilders urges government to support first-time buyers
articles.trailText: Taylor Wimpey chief Jennie Daly calls for revival of help-to-buy equity loan scheme to revive property market
articles.summary: Taylor Wimpey CEO Jennie Daly has called on the UK government to revive stamp duty relief or reintroduce a help-to-buy equity loan to lure first-time buyers and counter a cooled market shadowed by budget uncertainty. She argues a 75–80% LTV government-backed loan plus lower rates, alongside a 5–6% builder discount, could boost demand and help meet the 1.5m homes target. Daly warns build-cost inflation (up 20%) and piling green regulations—heat pumps, solar mandates, higher efficiency—risk making new housing unviable in lower-price areas. The government plans no new help-to-buy scheme.

articles.title: Life as a food delivery worker: ‘Sometimes men open the door naked’
articles.trailText: To earn a living as a delivery rider, some work 10-12 hour days, contending with low pay, exhaustion, accidents, injuries and harassment. Is this a new form of modern slavery?
articles.summary: UK food delivery riders—mostly migrants working for Deliveroo, Just Eat and Uber Eats—report low pay (£50-60/day by bike), 10-12 hour shifts, hazardous conditions, accidents and harassment—female riders face men opening doors nude or groping. Riders describe invisibility, exhaustion, modern slavery under app-driven algorithms with no managerial contact. Undocumented but legal by visa restrictions. Despite unions and sporadic minimum wage guarantees, riders lack rights, suffer financial, physical and mental strain. A 2023 Supreme Court ruling classifies riders as self-employed, limiting rights despite a 2021 Uber driver judgment. Academics call for a policy reset; platforms defend flexible work, pay and safety measures.

articles.title: Half of all UK jobs shed since Labour came to power are among under-25s
articles.trailText: Exclusive: David Blunkett warns Keir Starmer Britain’s youth are in danger of becoming ‘lost generation’ on his watch
articles.summary: Guardian analysis shows 46% of the 170,000 UK jobs lost since June 2024 have been held by under-25s, pushing youth unemployment to 15.3%, its highest outside the pandemic since 2015. Former education secretary David Blunkett warns of a ‘lost generation’ and urges a modernised New Deal. HMRC data reveal a 77,000 drop in under-25 payrolls, driven by under-18s, despite a 37,000 rebound in November. Critics blame Rachel Reeves’ £25bn national insurance hike for cuts in youth-heavy retail and hospitality, while Labour plans a Youth Guarantee, Alan Milburn review and expanded Youth Hubs to curb long-term unemployment, now 137,000 for 18-24s.

articles.title: ‘I have saved exactly £0’: how soaring costs have hit Britons’ nest eggs and pensions
articles.trailText: Tales of dwindling savings, frozen retirement pots and stringent frugality to put something aside for the future
articles.summary: Britons across income brackets report depleted savings and frozen pension contributions under surging living costs. Middle-class professionals—from Andrew in Essex (£4k in cash, £4k stocks, £30k pension) to Ryan in Glasgow (£0 saved) and Carrie in Manchester (no emergency fund despite a £70k pension pot)—describe living pay-slip to pay-slip amid high mortgages, rents, childcare and loans. Though 2020 lockdown saw record household savings, many have since dipped into funds, unauthorised Lifetime Isa withdrawals rose 139%, and while average savings hit £16,067, 39% hold £1,000 or less.

articles.title: Zip wires, darts, wild swimming: why shopping centres are trying new ways to bring in customers
articles.trailText: Developers are turning to health-related activities as traditional stores hit by online retail continue to close
articles.summary: Faced with falling footfall and empty stores after online retail growth, landlords are transforming shopping centres into experiential destinations anchored by sports and wellness: from zip lines, wild swimming, padel and climbing walls to high-tech golf simulators, football dining and bouncy castles. Projects include Wimbledon Quarter's Third Space gym and Golf Groove, Cardiff's leisure mall with padel courts and digital theatrics, Bluewater's planned rollercoasters and outdoor arena, and Wandsworth's Gravity go-karting and mini-golf. Tied to turnover-based rents, these leisure pivots cater to Gen Z and millennials' appetite for active, social 'self-improvement' experiences that online shopping can't deliver.

articles.title: About 1m Ford diesel cars sold in UK with defective emissions controls, court told
articles.trailText: Ford denies having created ‘defeat devices’ in legal action on behalf of 1.6 million owners against five carmakers
articles.summary: About 1m Ford diesel cars sold in the UK between 2016 and 2018 had defective NOx controls that failed under sulphur exposure, lawyers told the high court. In a suit for 1.6m owners, claimants allege Ford used “defeat devices” to pass Euro 6 tests—even as 27 vehicles flunked real-world NEDC trials. Ford acknowledges issues in some cars but disputes the scale. A 2018 software update was applied to production lines, yet no national recall occurred. Claimants cite internal memos showing calibration optimised for test conditions over emission cuts, echoing Dieselgate. Ford denies cheating, arguing its trade-offs were engineering necessities. Trial continues.

articles.title: Australia welcomes Trump’s removal of tariffs on beef and other food imports
articles.trailText: ‘We maintain our position that tariffs on any Australian products are unjustified,’ trade minister Don Farrell says
articles.summary: Australia’s government welcomed Donald Trump’s executive order rescinding the 10% US tariffs on beef, coffee, bananas and other agricultural imports—a policy he said reflected domestic demand and production capacity concerns amid inflation pressures. The levies, in effect since April, had hit AU beef producers shipping A$4bn to the US each year. Trade minister Don Farrell decried the tariffs as “economic self-harm,” while analysts, including Rabobank, say tariff repeal restores competitive parity, eases US consumer prices and bolsters free-trade ties. Long-term demand hinges on US herd recovery and potential tariff re-imposition. In 2024 bilateral trade hit A$23.8bn exports and A$50.5bn imports.

articles.title: Global markets struggle after tech sell-off and fears over Chinese economy
articles.trailText: Reaction follows Wall Street’s worst day in a month and unprecedented slump in investment in China
articles.summary: Global markets slid as a tech sell-off on Wall Street triggered its worst day in a month and weak Chinese data revealed a record 1.7% drop in fixed-asset investment for Jan–Oct. London’s FTSE 100 fell 1.1% to 9,698, with Barclays, Lloyds and NatWest down 2.7–3.6%, while the pound weakened after Chancellor Reeves abandoned planned income-tax rises. In New York, the S&P 500 finished flat, the Dow fell 0.7% and the Nasdaq gained 0.1%. Europe’s Stoxx 600 dropped 0.9%, Japan’s Nikkei lost 1.8%, Korea’s Kospi plunged 2.6% and Australia’s ASX declined 1.5%. Nvidia led a tech rout with a 3.6% slide after SoftBank sold its stake, dragging broader AI valuations lower. China’s CSI 300, Hong Kong’s Hang Seng and Taiwan’s Taiex fell 0.7%, 0.9% and 1.4% respectively. US markets also grappled with the longest federal shutdown delaying key data and dampening Fed rate-cut expectations.

articles.title: China voices ‘extreme disappointment’ with Dutch minister at centre of car chip row
articles.trailText: Vincent Karremans called semiconductor supply chain crisis a ‘wake-up call for western leaders’
articles.summary: Chinese government expressed extreme disappointment with Dutch economic affairs minister Vincent Karremans after he called the China-EU standoff over car chips a “wake-up call” for Western leaders. Beijing’s commerce ministry accused Karremans of distorting facts and improperly interfering with corporate operations, following The Hague’s move to place Nexperia—Wingtech’s Dutch subsidiary—under supervisory control over IP and security concerns. In retaliation, China imposed a global ban on Nexperia chip exports, slowing auto production. Karremans defended the action, citing intelligence of IP removal and production relocation. A Dutch delegation heads to Beijing next week, with Karremans due next month.

articles.title: People in the US: how are your holiday shopping plans being affected by Trump’s tariffs and the cost of living?
articles.trailText: We want to hear from people in the US about how Donald Trump’s economic policies may be affecting their plans for holiday shopping
articles.summary: This reader callout invites US consumers to share how holiday shopping plans are being shaped by rising costs and Trump administration’s tariff policies. With reports that officials may cut tariffs on coffee and fruit, propose 50-year mortgages, or fund $2,000 direct payments from tariff revenue, and amid a Harris poll finding 74% of households face over $100 in monthly cost increases, the piece seeks personal stories on Black Friday budgets, cost-of-living pressures, and tariff-driven price changes.

articles.title: Reeves’s plan to ditch income tax rise prompts government bond sell-off
articles.trailText: Switch in budget plan causes cost of UK government borrowing to rise by the most in a single day since early July
articles.summary: By ditching a manifesto-busting £30 bn income tax hike in her upcoming autumn budget, Rachel Reeves spooked markets: 10-year gilt yields jumped 0.13 pp to 4.575%, the pound slid 0.3% to $1.3155, and the FTSE 100 fell over 1% to 9,698. Investors, citing backbench rebellion and Labour infighting, worry the U-turn undermines fiscal credibility and raises the odds of a leadership shake-up toward a more left-wing team less committed to rebuilding headroom under OBR rules.

articles.title: ’Tis the season for dubious TV adverts | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers aren’t convinced by the wholesome family message peddled by John Lewis in its latest Christmas ad
articles.summary: Three Guardian readers challenge the new John Lewis Christmas advert’s purported warmth. One calls it a shameless marketing ploy to push overpriced gifts from a struggling retailer that hasn’t paid staff bonuses in years, warning ever-earlier festive campaigns add consumer pressure. A second disputes claims the ad harked back to a simpler 1990s, arguing debates on masculinity and fatherhood were already present then. A third criticizes the sidelining of women as background domestic figures, perpetuating gender stereotypes.

articles.title: US markets struggle amid tech sell-off and economic uncertainty
articles.trailText: Wall Street endured its worst day in a month on Thursday as fears that tech companies are now overvalued loom large
articles.summary: Wall Street suffered its worst session in a month as a tech-driven sell-off hit the S&P 500 and Dow 1.7%, while the Nasdaq fell 2.3%. Nvidia led declines, sliding 3.6% after SoftBank disclosed a $5.8 bn exit, stoking fears of AI-fueled overvaluation. Investors await key US economic releases on jobs and inflation now delayed by the 42-day government shutdown. Comments from Fed officials, including St. Louis Fed head Musalem and Trump adviser Kevin Hassett, have tempered expectations for imminent rate cuts. The Bureau of Labor Statistics cautioned it may need more time to finalize revised employment data.

articles.title: Thames Water tried to make MP pay its legal fees of up to £1,400 an hour
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Charlie Maynard accuses the utility of ‘retaliation’ over his push for government to gain control of company
articles.summary: Thames Water sought to force Lib Dem MP Charlie Maynard to pay up to £1,400 an hour in legal fees after he represented public interests in a Supreme Court challenge against its £17bn debt-backed bailout. The court rejected the demand, which Maynard condemned as ‘retaliation’ for urging a special administration regime to protect billpayers. Owned by hedge funds, the utility spent millions on lawyers to deter future appeals, prompting calls for urgent government intervention.

articles.title: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon to step down after more than a decade in role
articles.trailText: John Furner, the retail chain’s boss in the US, will succeed McMillion as global CEO after 31 January
articles.summary: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon, 59, will retire after leading the retailer since 2014, passing the global role to US head John Furner on February 1. Under McMillon’s tenure, Walmart scaled e-commerce, built a fast-growing ad business and sold Asda for £6.8 bn, delivering $681 bn in 2024 sales and an $800 bn market cap. Shares fell 3% premarket. Furner, 51, a 30-year veteran who previously ran Sam’s Club, assumes leadership amid broad sector turnover. McMillon will advise through early 2027. Chair Greg Penner hailed his impact in strengthening Walmart’s mission to help customers save and live better.

articles.title: ‘Red cup rebellion’: striking Starbucks baristas urge customers to stay away
articles.trailText: In Brooklyn, workers walked off the job in search of fair pay and conditions – and said many customers were in support
articles.summary: In Brooklyn’s Clinton Hill on Nov 14, over a thousand Starbucks Workers United members across 40+ US cities staged a “red cup rebellion” strike on the chain’s red cup day to demand fair pay, improved staffing and resolution of unfair labor practice claims after stalled contract talks. Baristas picketed in 40°F weather, chanting “No contract, no coffee,” and deterred roughly half of potential customers, met with boos if they entered. Management drafted in supervisors to keep one store open. Union allies, community supporters and leaders like Assembly Member Claire Valdez and AFT President Randi Weingarten joined picket lines. Since 2021, 650+ stores have unionized despite corporate pushback.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover slides to loss of almost £500m after cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Carmaker reports £196m of exceptional direct costs in addressing hack as it returns to full output
articles.summary: JLR reported a third-quarter pre-tax loss of £485m for July–September after a cyber-attack halted production across its UK and overseas factories in September, reversing a £398m profit a year earlier and ending 11 consecutive profitable quarters. The hack incurred £196m of direct remediation costs, with wider UK economic losses estimated up to £1.9bn and GDP growth trimmed to 0.1%. Factories have since restarted “at or approaching capacity.” JLR also cites Trump-era US tariffs, the phase-out of older Jaguar models and delayed launches of new electric Range Rover and Jaguar EVs. The group has drawn £500m of a £2bn bank facility but has not tapped a £1.5bn government guarantee.

articles.title: Atom is prematurely split in the ‘golden age’ transatlantic partnership | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Britain was always going to prefer homegrown technology for the SMR reactors at Wylfe. The US would have done the same
articles.summary: In a test of the UK-US nuclear “golden age,” the UK has awarded its Wylfa SMR site to British firm Rolls-Royce SMR for three 470 MW small modular reactors, snubbing Westinghouse and disappointing the US ambassador. Wylfa’s government-owned land and nuclear legacy make it ideal for demonstrating SMR cost advantages over mega-plants, though prefabrication savings remain unproven. Critics deem three units too few; the site could expand to eight, matching or exceeding Hinkley Point C’s capacity. London insists home bias was inevitable, offering Westinghouse future bids on large-scale projects, while export prospects hinge on mid-2030s output and proven cost declines.

articles.title: Ineos to cut hundreds of jobs as carmaker struggles with debts
articles.trailText: Company owned by billionaire Jim Ratcliffe says it is simplifying its head office to improve efficiency
articles.summary: Ineos Automotive, owned by billionaire Jim Ratcliffe, will cut “several hundred” of its 1,700 head office jobs across the UK and Europe to simplify its structure amid mounting debt. Its Hambach plant in France—producing the Grenadier off-road vehicle—remains unaffected despite recalls of 7,000 units in the US over door faults and higher US tariffs. Parent Ineos has closed two German chemicals plants and cut 20% of East Yorkshire staff, blaming energy costs and cheap Chinese imports, and is filing EU anti-dumping cases. Fitch and Moody’s warn its debt is nearing €12bn (eight times annual earnings).

articles.title: ‘Whatever it takes’: Starbucks workers launch US strike and call for boycott
articles.trailText: Unfair labor practice strike on ‘red cup day’ in over 25 cities comes amid stagnant negotiations with coffee chain
articles.summary: On its annual ‘red cup day’, over 1,000 Starbucks Workers United members in 65 stores across 40+ US cities launched an unfair labor practice strike, demanding completion of their first union contract amid stalled negotiations and alleged management stonewalling. Branded “no contract, no coffee,” the action targets slow talks since 2021’s first Starbucks union vote (now 650+ shops). Baristas seek better staffing, pay and resolution of hundreds of ULP charges; Starbucks, representing 96% non-union staff, calls its offer “best in retail” and says most outlets remain unaffected.

articles.title: Liberty Steel being investigated in Romania for embezzlement
articles.trailText: Metals firm denies allegations as more problems emerge for founder Sanjeev Gupta after loss of key UK operation
articles.summary: Romanian prosecutors have raided seven homes and the registered office of a Liberty Steel operation in Galați and Bucharest, accusing the Gupta Family Group Alliance’s metals arm of embezzlement and tax evasion. Investigators allege managers used fictitious goods contracts, sham loans and offshore affiliates—including a €137m CO2 certificate sale to Gazprom via Singapore—to divert investment funds. The probe, part of wider Romanian business raids, compounds Sanjeev Gupta’s troubles after the 2021 Greensill collapse, UK Serious Fraud Office scrutiny and the loss of key UK and Australian steelworks. GFG insists all transfers benefited Galați, were vetted by external lawyers and clean-audited.

articles.title: Scotland plans to issue £1.5bn of its own bonds – ‘kilts’ rather than gilts
articles.trailText: Announcement by first minister John Swinney comes after Moody’s and S&P give country same credit rating as UK
articles.summary: Scotland’s first minister John Swinney says Edinburgh will issue £1.5bn of “kilts” – its own bonds – after Moody’s (Aa3) and S&P (AA) matched the UK’s rating. Proceeds will fund capital investment, leveraging devolution powers since 2015 under strict limits. Swinney highlights prudent fiscal management and balanced budgets. If re-elected in May on 35% support vs Labour’s 19%, the SNP plans to raise the £1.5bn across the next parliament, asserting financial maturity. Though modest vs £300bn UK issuance, this establishes borrowing autonomy. Moody’s cautioned independence could pressure the rating by introducing institutional uncertainty and financial stability risks.

articles.title: Oversupply of oil could create glut of 4m barrels a day, says energy watchdog
articles.trailText: Warning comes as scenario in which global demand continues to grow until 2050 is included in IEA outlook report
articles.summary: IEA warns global oil output will exceed demand by about 4m barrels per day in 2026, larger than previously forecast, despite major producers pausing export hikes. Slow demand growth contrasts with rising supply—forecast up 3.1m bpd in 2025 and 2.5m bpd in 2026—fueling a lopsided market. Monthly report lifted 2026 surplus estimate from 3.97m to 4.09m bpd. In its energy outlook, it reintroduced a scenario of oil demand rising to 2050, sparking debate over EV uptake and renewables momentum. All scenarios project renewable energy doubling in five years and peak oil by 2030 under strong clean-energy adoption.

articles.title: Burberry bosses urge Rachel Reeves to reinstate tax-free shopping for tourists
articles.trailText: British luxury brand urges chancellor to pursue ‘progressive policies’ in budget to increase spending sprees by foreigners
articles.summary: Burberry’s executives have called on Chancellor Rachel Reeves to reinstate the VAT refund scheme for overseas tourists—abolished in 2020 and briefly reintroduced then scrapped in 2022—to recapture luxury shoppers who now favor Paris and Milan. CEO Joshua Schulman said restoring tax-free shopping would boost visitor spending, support jobs and stimulate growth across the UK’s visitor economy. Burberry reported a 2% rise in Q2 comparable store sales and halved its half-year loss to £48m (including a £37m restructuring charge). The company plans up to 1,700 job cuts by 2027 to reduce costs, restore profitability and generate free cash flow.

articles.title: Amid disappointing UK growth, how can Rachel Reeves escape the doom loop?
articles.trailText: Stronger public finances require stronger economy, but large tax rises and spending cuts could squeeze activity further
articles.summary: Facing a potential “doom loop” of weak growth and strained public finances, Chancellor Rachel Reeves must balance large tax rises and spending cuts against the risk of further depressing activity in her November budget. GDP growth slowed to 0.1% in Q3 from 0.3%, hampered by a 28.6% collapse at Jaguar Land Rover after a cyber-attack. Consumer-facing services output and business investment fell, unemployment reached four-year highs and inflation remains near 4%. Bond-market jitters over a potential £30 billion fiscal shortfall add to uncertainty. With the UK still the second-fastest G7 grower but confidence fragile, Reeves needs targeted growth measures to rebuild momentum and satisfy fiscal rules.

articles.title: UK economy grew by just 0.1% in third quarter after hit from JLR cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Figure undershoots forecasts, with Jaguar Land Rover hack helping to pull September GDP down by 0.1%
articles.summary: UK economy expanded 0.1% in Q3 to September, down from 0.3% in Q2 and below the 0.2% forecast, as GDP fell 0.1% in September. A 28.6% slump in motor vehicle output following a Jaguar Land Rover cyber-attack drove a 2% fall in manufacturing. Services growth slowed to 0.2%, construction rose 0.1%, business investment dropped 0.3% and unemployment hit 5%. Softer data fuel markets’ bets on a BoE rate cut in December. Chancellor Reeves faces a crunch budget on 26 November amid downgraded forecasts and tax-hike pressures.

articles.title: ‘I’d do it all again,’ says Dutch minister at heart of car chip standoff with China
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Vincent Karremans says six-week row with Beijing that threatened global car production is ‘wake-up call’
articles.summary: Dutch economy minister Vincent Karremans led a six-week EU-China standoff over Nexperia, a Chinese-owned chipmaker vital to global car production, by taking supervisory control on Sept 30 under a Cold War-era law amid intelligence of IP and wafer relocations to China. Beijing retaliated by halting exports, paralyzing car plants and igniting supply chaos in Europe and Mexico. After a Trump-Xi deal in South Korea resumed chip flows, Karremans says he’d do it again, calling it a "wake-up call" on Europe’s tech dependency and pledging to hold controls until deliveries are stable.

articles.title: Hybrid working could help get more disabled people into work, peers say
articles.trailText: Lords committee says government should consider including remote working in back-to-work initiatives
articles.summary: The cross-party House of Lords Home-Based Working committee urges ministers to back hybrid and remote work in back-to-work schemes to improve disabled people’s and carers’ employment. Evidence highlights that avoiding commutes, flexible hours and remote options aid health management, broaden talent pools, cut sickness absence and boost recruitment. Yet 28% of UK workers enjoy hybrid roles, mostly professionals, graduates and Londoners; many lack manager training. While employees prefer two office days vs employers’ three, peers recommend government guidance and employer incentives over new legislation. Few outliers like Amazon still mandate full-time attendance.

articles.title: The 5% first home buyers scheme is a miserable policy failure – and the latest chapter in Australia’s housing disgrace | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: The government is juicing demand to make houses more expensive for Australians while providing good public housing for … Americans
articles.summary: Over 25 years, successive Australian governments have juiced housing demand—via investor tax incentives and first-home buyer grants—while public housing supply has dwindled. The 5% deposit guarantee, launched October, slashes the deposit on an $800,000 home from $160,000 to $40,000 (a $120,000 implicit grant), triggering more first-home buyers and an 18% quarterly leap in investor loans—now over 40% of new mortgages, especially in NSW and VIC. Housing finance growth, which had slowed, now points to renewed price rises. Despite slightly higher building approvals, public-housing stock remains negligible, even as Defence Housing is repurposed for US sailors under AUKUS—a policy failure.

articles.title: SSE is a winner in the great grid upgrade. Who is looking out for consumers and small businesses? | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Nobody doubts chunky spending is necessary to improve the grid. But how much of that money will be funded through consumer bills?
articles.summary: SSE’s planned £33bn grid overhaul over five years — more than its current market value — has sent shares 17% higher. It needs only £2bn of new equity plus similar proceeds from disposals to fund this boost, and forecasts dividends growing 5–10% annually through 2030. Ofgem’s draft price controls front-load £80bn of network charges across SSE, Scottish Power and National Grid, hiking bills by ~20%. Domestic households could see a £42 uplift next April, while SMEs face network cost rises of 70%, adding 5–10% to total bills. Critics urge regulators and government to address the affordability impact more openly.

articles.title: Atlanta Fed chair steps down as Trump attacks central bank’s independence
articles.trailText: Raphael W Bostic will retire in February – creating another vacancy on Federal Reserve’s powerful policy committee
articles.summary: Atlanta Fed President Raphael W. Bostic announced he will retire in February, creating a vacancy on the Federal Reserve’s influential policy committee amid former President Donald Trump’s campaign to influence central bank decisions. Bostic, 59, could have served six more years and is the first African American and openly gay regional Fed president. His departure follows the resignation of board governor Adriana Kugler. The Atlanta Fed will conduct a nationwide search for a successor. Bostic praised the bank’s work on inclusive growth; Fed Chair Jerome Powell lauded his analytical rigor and public service.

articles.title: ‘Part of the joy economy’: bumper year for UK toys as Wicked dolls and Pokémon appeal to ‘kidults’
articles.trailText: Some of this year’s Christmas must-haves also expected to appeal to older generations
articles.summary: UK’s toy market enjoyed a bumper year as adult ‘kidults’ (12+) now drive one third of spend, with 43% of adults (76% gen Z) purchasing toys for themselves or other adults. January–June children’s toy sales rose 6%, buoyed by nostalgia and self-care. DreamToys’ Christmas list—from £35 Wicked 2 singing dolls and manga Lego to £120 One Piece ship, Pokémon Elite Trainer Box and £20 Fill the Fridge playset—underscores the sector’s resilience in the ‘joy economy’ despite looming budget-driven spending pressures.

articles.title: Housebuilder Taylor Wimpey hit by sales fall amid budget uncertainty
articles.trailText: Weekly average for number of private sales per site drops 11% in key autumn period as property tax rumours swirl
articles.summary: Taylor Wimpey saw its weekly average private sales per site fall 11% to 0.63 between 30 June and 9 November (vs 0.71 a year earlier), amid uncertainty ahead of the UK budget and rumoured property taxes on homes over £500,000. Its order book declined 7% by volume to 7,253 homes (value £2.1 bn) from 7,771. Year-to-date sales are marginally down at 0.72 per site. While pricing is expected to remain flat and build costs rise modestly, Taylor Wimpey reaffirms full-year guidance for completions and operating profit, citing resilient fundamentals.

articles.title: Menulog closing in Australia, affecting thousands of delivery drivers and 120 employees
articles.trailText: Transport Workers’ Union says it will be seeking to ensure workers receive fair exit payments before 26 November closure
articles.summary: Just Eat Takeaway.com will shut Menulog’s Australian operations on 26 November, ending its 20-year run. The move affects about 120 direct employees, who will receive redundancy packages, and tens of thousands of gig couriers. The Transport Workers’ Union warns riders—who work across multiple apps and lack entitlements like sick leave or super—face below-minimum wages and will press for fair exit payments. Menulog plans a voluntary four-week payout for couriers with at least six months’ tenure and recent deliveries, calculated on average earnings. Closure follows pandemic-era industry shake-outs (Deliveroo in 2022, Voly) and leaves Uber Eats and DoorDash dominant; unused vouchers can be redeemed before shutdown.

articles.title: SoftBank sells stake in Nvidia for $5.8bn as it doubles down on OpenAI bets
articles.trailText: Shares in chipmaker Nvidia fall after announcement by Japanese investor, with other tech shares also slipping
articles.summary: SoftBank sold its NVIDIA stake for $5.8 billion in October to bankroll over $30 billion in OpenAI investments, driving Q2 net profit above 2.5 trn yen on OpenAI valuation gains. It also trimmed T-Mobile holdings. CFO Yoshimitsu Goto said the divestment wasn’t triggered by Nvidia’s outlook but by the need to deploy existing assets for AI bets. Nvidia shares fell 3.5%, pulling the Nasdaq down 0.85%, while Arm and Micron slid over 5%. The deal underscores a pivot from Nvidia’s peak $5 trn market cap to OpenAI’s evolving growth prospects. Analysts called it profit-taking ahead of a potential AI market peak.

articles.title: ‘You can’t spend your whole life trying to stop a McDonald’s’: how the fast-food chain keeps opening new Australian stores
articles.trailText: Darebin city council has rejected a 24-hour store in the Melbourne suburb of Northcote. But will community opposition hold?
articles.summary: Melbourne’s Darebin council narrowly rejected McDonald’s plan for a 24-hour outlet in Northcote after an 11,000-signature petition, setting up a probable VCAT appeal. Experts highlight the chain’s well-resourced, long-game strategy: deploying high-paid lawyers, lobbying planning codes (eg, 1994 Kennett amendments reclassifying takeaways), and using complying development certificates to bypass councils. McDonald’s often compromises on traffic or trading-hour tweaks but never abandons expansion. Owning and leasing key sites—while 85% of its 1,000+ Australian stores are franchised—the company fills network gaps nationwide, confident community groups will burn out before it does.

articles.title: UK grocery price inflation slows as retailers launch pre-Christmas promotions
articles.trailText: Prices are rising fastest in markets such as chocolate confectionery, fresh meat and coffee, figures show
articles.summary: Grocery inflation cooled to 4.7% in the four weeks to 2 Nov from 5.2% amid aggressive pre-Christmas promotions, data from Worldpanel by Numerator show. Prices rose fastest for chocolate confectionery, fresh meat and coffee, while kitchen roll, toilet paper, sugar confectionery and dog food fell most. High-promotion sales jumped 9.4% versus 1.8% on full-priced goods as households traded down to own-label and discounters. Lidl led growth with a 10.8% sales rise; Tesco and Sainsbury’s gained share; Asda fell 3.9%. Upmarket M&S (+8.8%) and Ocado (+15.9%) benefited from rising incomes, prompting analysts to warn budget pressures may drive further shift to discounters.

articles.title: UK unemployment rises to 5%, the highest level in four years
articles.trailText: ONS says jobs market worsening before budget, as HMRC reports falling number of workers on firms’ payrolls
articles.summary: ONS data show UK unemployment climbed to 5.0% in the three months to Sept—the highest since Jan 2021—leaving 1.8 million jobless. HMRC payroll figures fell by 180,000 y/y and monthly pay growth eased to 4.8%, fueling expectations of a December Bank of England rate cut. The pound dipped 0.3% vs. the dollar even as the FTSE hit a record 9,899. Economists cite pre-budget jitters and last April’s NI rise for hiring cuts, notably in retail, hospitality and IT. Youth unemployment topped a decade high—NEETs near 1 million—prompting independent reviews by Alan Milburn and Charlie Mayfield. Chancellor Reeves faces a £30 billion fiscal gap and plans further tax rises on earners. Ministers tout jobcentre modernisation, expanded youth hubs and health partnerships to boost workforce participation.

articles.title: Rising unemployment could affect budget, interest rates, pay and more
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves will need to avoid depressing economy and hitting jobs while raising billions in extra tax
articles.summary: Rising unemployment (4.8% to 5.0%, 1.8m jobless) poses a dilemma for chancellor Rachel Reeves ahead of her 26 November budget: raising tens of billions in new taxes while avoiding deeper job losses. Employers are already grappling with higher employment costs, and planned measures—steep national insurance hikes and an above-inflation minimum wage rise—risk further weakening hiring incentives. Meanwhile, wage growth slowed from 5% to 4.8% in September and may fall to 3.1%, reinforcing BoE expectations of a December interest-rate cut. The widening public–private pay gap (6.8% vs. 4.4%) and evaporating labour hoarding compound pressures.

articles.title: Wessex Water must pay £11m over wastewater failures, says regulator
articles.trailText: Company failed to effectively operate, maintain and upgrade its wastewater assets, Ofwat finds
articles.summary: Ofwat has ordered Wessex Water and its shareholders to fund an £11 million enforcement package—covered outside customer bills—after finding the company failed to operate, maintain and upgrade its wastewater network adequately, causing unlawful sewage spills. Serving Bristol, Dorset, Somerset and parts of Wiltshire, Gloucestershire and Hampshire, Wessex must seal private sewer pipes, install extra monitoring, accelerate storm-overflow upgrades and support customer rainwater management. This is the sixth of Ofwat’s major sector investigations, following over £240 million in penalties levied on five other water firms this year.

articles.title: Nexperia row shows how China is weaponising EU relationship - and winning
articles.trailText: Experts say Brussels must stand up against Beijing using supplies of vital chips and minerals as ‘sword of Damocles’
articles.summary: Beijing’s brief restriction then 12-month conditional resumption of Nexperia automotive chip exports after the Dutch takeover exposed how China leverages vital semiconductors, rare earths and magnets as geopolitical tools. Europe’s €300bn trade deficit and 95% reliance on Chinese rare earths leave its auto, defense and clean-tech industries under a constant “sword of Damocles.” Despite EU de-risking policies, member states lag in diversifying supply chains. Calls grow for invoking the new anti-coercion instrument, imposing counter-measures and reducing strategic dependencies to counter Beijing’s asymmetric power.

articles.title: UK retail sales growth slows as shoppers await Black Friday and budget
articles.trailText: Industry body says shoppers are waiting for discount day, as Barclays reports falling consumer confidence
articles.summary: UK retail sales rose 1.6% in October, down from 2.3% in September and their weakest pace since May, as shoppers delayed purchases for Black Friday deals and looming budget tax changes. Food sales growth slowed to 3.5% (-0.8pp) and non-food was flat at 0.1%, with falls in footwear, stationery and appliances amid milder weather. Barclays found all seven consumer confidence measures fell, with household finances confidence down from 74% to 63%, and card spending down 0.8%. Retailers warn pre-budget uncertainty risks undermining Black Friday’s crucial sales boost.

articles.title: Can ex-Tesco boss Drastic Dave refresh the fortunes of drinks giant Diageo?
articles.trailText: City heavyweight has cheered the markets by taking helm at Guinness owner, but there may be forces he cannot overcome
articles.summary: Diageo’s shares rallied by £2bn after appointing ex-Tesco chief Dave Lewis, credited for cost cuts at Unilever and Tesco, to revive the ailing Guinness owner. Facing a decade-low share price, pandemic hangover, supply missteps under Debra Crew and long-term declines in alcohol consumption—exacerbated by cost-of-living pressures, Trump’s tariffs and weight-loss drugs—Lewis may pursue brand divestments, portfolio pruning and dividend adjustments. Yet macro headwinds and generational sobriety could limit his “Drastic Dave” fixes.

articles.title: Troubled drinks giant Diageo names former Tesco boss to lead turnaround push
articles.trailText: Appointment of Sir Dave Lewis as CEO represents significant coup for struggling FTSE 100 firm
articles.summary: Diageo has named Sir Dave Lewis, ex‐Tesco CEO credited with a five‐year turnaround after its 2014 accounting scandal, as its new chief executive from Jan 1. Tasked with reversing a one‐third share slump, profit warning, tariff headwinds and supply‐chain missteps that led to Guinness rationing and overstock in Latin America, he replaces Debra Crew. Interim CFO Nik Jhangiani returns to his role year‐end. Lewis, who chairs Haleon and once spent 30 years at Unilever, will relinquish posts but retain his Xlinks chair. Analysts caution his lack of direct spirits experience may delay strategic reset amid tough trading conditions. Shares rose 7% on the announcement.

articles.title: Lloyds the landlord: how the bank quietly became a big rental property player
articles.trailText: Bank has a £2bn rental property portfolio via its Lloyds Living arm, amassing 7,000 properties so far with plans to add 43,000 more by 2030
articles.summary: Lloyds Bank’s Lloyds Living arm has built a £2bn residential portfolio of 7,500 homes since its July 2021 launch, offering rentals and shared ownership across 42 suburban sites. With targets to reach 50,000 properties by 2030, it funds build-to-rent deals with Barratt Redrow and converts offices into discounted social housing. Lloyds uses rentals to diversify income amid low rates and convened a social housing conference with Angela Rayner, though its gains are overshadowed by a costly car loans commission scandal.

articles.title: Growth in global demand for ‘green’ office buildings slows amid Trump policies
articles.trailText: Fall reported by Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors as UN calls for accelerated action in buildings sector to meet global climate goals
articles.summary: RICS survey finds growth in demand for green office buildings has slowed worldwide, especially in the Americas where interest fell sharply—US expansion balances dropped from 25% to 11%—following Trump’s environmental deregulation. Outside the Americas, growth balances dipped to 40% from 48% in 2021. The UN warns buildings produce 34% of global emissions, driven by heating, cooling and construction. Despite cost and tenant benefits of low-carbon materials, efficiency improvements and renewables, confidence has waned amid policy rollbacks. Embodied carbon measurement declined to 46% of projects not tracked, and only 16% of firms use carbon data to guide design.

articles.title: US private equity giant poised to take over online retailer The Very Group
articles.trailText: Barclay family set to lose another part of former business empire, once known as Littlewoods, to Carlyle Group
articles.summary: Carlyle Group is set to acquire online retailer The Very Group from the Barclay family, ending over 20 years of their ownership since buying Littlewoods in 2002 and capping a series of disposals of assets such as the Telegraph and Ritz. The takeover, approved by a board chaired by ex-chancellor Nadhim Zahawi, follows Carlyle's financing build-up from 2021 to over £500m. Abu Dhabi's IMI will remain a lender. Very reported £307m EBITDA and £2.1bn sales to 28 June. Both parties declined to comment.

articles.title: Last Christmas, you gave us first class: Royal Mail turns Scrooge with gift to staff of second-class stamps
articles.trailText: Switch comes amid first festive season since Daniel Křetínský’s takeover of parent company IDS
articles.summary: This Christmas, Royal Mail gave staff 50 second-class stamps instead of the usual first-class booklet—a first since Czech billionaire Daniel Křetínský’s IDS takeover. Free seasonal stamps, launched under Tony Benn in 1966, reward postal workers during the peak. A sheet of 50 first-class stamps costs £85 versus £43.50 for second-class, marking a significant saving. The downgrade has drawn ire from the Communication Workers Union and employees, who say it undervalues their service; Royal Mail points to universal service obligation changes to justify the switch.

articles.title: I’m as capitalist as they get but Medicare for all is the best hope for US healthcare | Gene Marks
articles.trailText: With the US government shut down over impending rises to insurance premiums it’s clear the status quo cannot continue
articles.summary: Business columnist Gene Marks argues that the complex, costly US private insurance model—where families now average $27,000 annual premiums and employers are set to pay $17,000 per employee next year—is unsustainable, as evidenced by the government shutdown over expiring tax credits. He proposes expanding Medicare “for all” via means-tested payroll contributions (both employee and employer), mirroring the UK’s 5.3%/13.75% approach, and outsourcing administration to third-party managers. This would simplify plan selection, level the playing field for small businesses, reduce administrative burden, and improve public health, outperforming the ACA without overhauling existing provider networks.

articles.title: UK banks still committed to climate goals, Bank of England executive insists
articles.trailText: Exclusive: David Bailey plays down concerns after HSBC and Barclays quit UN-backed Net Zero Banking Alliance
articles.summary: David Bailey, executive director of prudential policy at the Bank of England’s PRA, insisted UK banks remain “vibrantly” committed to climate goals despite HSBC and Barclays quitting the UN-backed Net Zero Banking Alliance and its closure in October after US banks had departed. He said firms engage actively with the PRA on climate risk, with further stress tests possible, balanced against emerging risks such as unregulated private credit. Bailey, seen as a frontrunner to succeed PRA chief Sam Woods, also touted the forthcoming “strong and simple” regime to ease rules for smaller lenders, a key plank in the government’s growth agenda.

articles.title: The bond market is wrong. Reeves should not cut welfare to placate the City | Richard Partington
articles.trailText: Keeping the markets on side is the chancellor’s priority but it’s not an easy task given their simplistic, misplaced views on welfare cuts
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves faces her first OBR verdict ahead of her November budget, with bond markets wielding more influence than official forecasts. Recent falling gilt yields, aided by US moves and her fiscal discipline rhetoric, have tempered borrowing costs. City investors insist on public spending cuts—especially to welfare—to signal budget toughness, warning tax hikes could cripple growth. But such a stance, critics argue, ignores Britain’s ageing, health-burdened population and the welfare state’s stabilising role. Welfare outlays remain flat as a share of GDP, with pension and health benefits driving most growth. Cutting benefits risks higher poverty and weaker domestic demand, undermining growth and long-term fiscal sustainability.

articles.title: Drax still burning 250-year-old trees sourced from forests in Canada, experts say
articles.trailText: Exclusive: report by Stand.earth says subsidiary of power plant received truckloads of whole logs at biomass pellet sites
articles.summary: A Stand.earth report using British Columbia government data and satellite monitoring finds Drax’s Canadian subsidiary imported hundreds of whole-log truckloads of old-growth wood through 2024–25, including at least 90 loads from 250-year-old forests in the Skeena region and another 425 from cutblocks with over 80% ancient trees. The findings challenge Drax’s sustainability claims and its policy of sourcing from ‘well-managed’ forests, even as it secures more than £2m daily in UK green energy subsidies and faces increased regulatory scrutiny.

articles.title: US consumer sentiment drops to near record low as shutdown persists
articles.trailText: Economic concerns felt by Americans of different ages, incomes and political affiliations, survey finds
articles.summary: US consumer sentiment dropped 6% in November to an index reading of 50.3—below the 53.0 economists had forecast—marking its lowest level since June 2022 and the lowest overall since at least 1978, as the federal government shutdown stretched past a month. The decline was broad-based across age, income and political groups, according to the University of Michigan survey. With federal data releases halted, investors turned to ADP’s report of only 42,000 new private-sector jobs in October and Challenger, Gray & Christmas’s count of 153,074 layoffs—the highest October total since 2003.

articles.title: Lose weight or risk losing your job, chunky oil rig workers told
articles.trailText: North Sea oil and gas rig staff need to be under 124.7kg so they can be safely winched on to helicopter in emergency
articles.summary: North Sea operators will require all rig staff to weigh no more than 124.7 kg fully clothed by November next year or face offshore work bans, according to Offshore Energies UK. The new safety threshold, aimed at ensuring safe helicopter winch rescue, directly affects about 2,500 workers above the limit and a further 2,500 who may need weight‐management support. Industry health and safety manager Graham Skinner said the association will partner with employers over the next 12 months to provide dietary and fitness programmes. The policy follows rising offshore workforce weights and a two‐year cross‐industry review of rescue equipment limitations.

articles.title: Three big problems with ITV’s talks to sell television business to Sky: price, politics and regulation | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: On price, is £1.6bn the most the media and entertainment arm could fetch? The other hurdles look just as immense
articles.summary: ITV is in talks to sell its broadcasting arm to Sky (Comcast) for £1.6bn, sparking three major issues: the price seems low for a unit generating £250m in annual operating profit and ~£2bn in revenue; UK competition authorities may block consolidation of leading free-to-air and pay-TV outfits; and US ownership raises concerns over media plurality, Sky News funding, and public service obligations. Despite CEO Carolyn McCall’s cost cuts, studio growth and launch of ITVX, ITV’s market value stays subdued, prompting a deal to unlock shareholder value, though Sky/Comcast may not be the best fit.

articles.title: China poised to lift ban on chips exports to European carmakers after US deal
articles.trailText: Dispute began with Dutch government takeover of Nexperia and China halting exports, threatening car production
articles.summary: Last week’s Trump-Xi South Korea deal delays US affiliate rule on Wingtech for 12 months and in return China agreed to suspend its export ban on Nexperia chips and rare-earth minerals. The standoff began when the Netherlands seized Nexperia over security concerns about its Chinese owner, prompting Beijing to halt exports, threatening European and Japanese car assembly. Dutch economy minister Vincent Karremans says Nexperia shipments to Europe should resume imminently, echoed by German supplier Aumovio’s CEO after receiving written exemption. Final resolution may see the Dutch order shelved once exports restart, underscoring global auto supply chain vulnerabilities.

articles.title: ITV shares soar as it holds talks to sell television business to Sky
articles.trailText: US telecom firm Comcast aims to buy media and entertainment arm for £1.6bn but analysts question valuation, potential job cuts and regulatory concerns
articles.summary: ITV has entered preliminary talks with Comcast’s Sky parent to sell its UK broadcasting arm—including free-to-air channels and the ITVX streaming service—for £1.6bn (excluding ITV Studios). The announcement sent its shares up 16% on the FTSE 250, but analysts warn the offer undervalues the unit and could trigger heavy job cuts. Regulators (CMA, Ofcom) may demand remedies if the combined ad‐sales operations control over 70% of the UK market. ITV also plans a £35m cost cut as Q4 advertising revenues face a 9% decline.

articles.title: Qantas business lounge passenger set on fire after power bank explodes in his pocket
articles.trailText: About 150 people evacuated from Melbourne airport lounge after device overheats and ignites, burning the man’s leg and fingers
articles.summary: A passenger in Qantas’s Melbourne international business lounge suffered leg and finger burns when a lithium-ion power bank in his pocket overheated and ignited, prompting paramedics to treat him on site and his transfer to hospital. Around 150 people were evacuated as a precaution, the lounge was cleaned in coordination with airport authorities, and has since reopened. The incident, coming a day before Qantas’s AGM, underscores growing airline scrutiny of battery carriage policies and follows similar Virgin Australia power-bank fires.

articles.title: Driving competition: China’s carmakers in race to dominate Europe’s roads
articles.trailText: Chinese manufacturers are using the electric transition to seize market share, with the UK as their gateway
articles.summary: Chinese automakers backed by state subsidies are leveraging Europe’s electric transition to gain market share, using the UK—accounting for 30% of Chinese EV sales in western Europe—as a gateway. Brands like BYD, Chery’s Omoda and Jaecoo, SAIC’s MG, Geely’s Volvo/Polestar and newcomers Xpeng and Leapmotor have surged by undercutting pricing, offering advanced tech, hybrids excluded from EU tariffs. The UK’s open market, climate targets and lack of domestic manufacturers have fueled fierce competition, reminiscent of 1980s Japanese entry. Domestic overcapacity drives exports, threatening 2m European sales and factory takeovers.

articles.title: Sky owner Comcast in talks to buy ITV’s broadcasting arm for about £2bn
articles.trailText: Deal would exclude ITV Studios but would mark major shake-up of UK television
articles.summary: Comcast, the US media conglomerate that acquired Sky for £30bn in 2018, is in talks to buy ITV’s broadcasting business—including its TV channels and streaming service ITVX—for about £2bn. The deal excludes ITV Studios, whose value may exceed the core broadcaster and is under separate takeover interest. ITV’s market value has fallen to £2.5bn amid streaming competition and a pending 9% drop in Q4 ad revenues, prompting a £35m budget cut. Liberty Global recently halved its 10% stake. Advisers are Robey Warshaw and Morgan Stanley; the companies declined comment.

articles.title: US markets tumble amid Wall Street concern over job losses and AI
articles.trailText: S&P 500 down 1.1% and Nasdaq down 1.9% as hiring freezes and layoffs sharpen fears US economy is slowing
articles.summary: Wall Street tumbled—S&P 500 -1.1%, Nasdaq -1.9%—after October’s US layoffs surged to 153,074 (worst since 2003) with 1.09 m cuts YTD (+44% y/y) and widespread hiring freezes (Challenger, Gray & Christmas). A government shutdown delayed inflation and jobs data, leaving the Fed “groping in the dark” (Fed’s Goolsbee) and cautious on rate cuts. Tech valuations driven by AI investments sparked bubble fears. Europe fell too: Stoxx Europe 600 -0.7%, DAX -1.3%, as a Supreme Court tariff review added policy uncertainty.

articles.title: British Airways to offer free fast onboard wifi to all after Starlink deal
articles.trailText: Service will be offered to customers in economy, business and first class alike from next year
articles.summary: British Airways will offer free lightning-fast, reliable Wi-Fi from Starlink to economy, business and first class passengers from next year, covering 500+ aircraft across IAG carriers. Part of a £7 billion transformation, gate-to-gate connectivity requires no special login and supports multiple devices. CEO Sean Doyle calls it “gamechanging” vs competitors on short haul. BA’s current .air service charges £4.99–£21.99 for streaming outside first class. The move follows BA’s improved punctuality, rising profits and IAG’s upcoming Q3 results.
